mutationSurveillance.hostLevel: Mutations at the host-level are also called intrahost variants. These are mutations that occur at a given frequency (0 - 1) within a given sample.
mutationSurveillance.populationLevel: Mutations at the population-level are those identified in the consensus genomes.
mutationSurveillance.phenotype: To assess the importance of mutations found at the host- or population-level, we use phenotypic measurements such as deep mutational scanning (Dadonaite et al. 2024). In the plot below, we show the number of samples a mutation was identified in and the corresponding phenotypic measurement. You can find more details about deep mutational scanning data on DMS VEP.
mutationSurveillance.phenotypeByCollectionDate: If there is evolutionary pressure to select for a given phenotype, we would expect the proportion of distinct mutations with a measurement over a threshold to increase over time.
mutationSurveillance.phenotypeAggregateBySample: We aggregate phenotypic measurements for every sample by summing over all the sites in the genome.
mutationSurveillance.literatureAnnotationsOverTime: We rely on FluMut, a resource for annotations of mutations in influenza from scientific literature, to highlight the number of mutations with a given annotation over time.
